Award.AwardTitle: 2014-15 Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program provides a unique professional development opportunity for K-12 educators to inform national STEM policy and improve communication between the STEM education community and national leaders. Albert Einstein Fellows spend eleven months working at the National Science Foundation, bringing extensive knowledge and STEM classroom experience to the agency. In addition, fellows are provided with an extensive program of professional development training during their fellowship year. The Albert Einstein Fellows program is run by the non-profit Triangle Coalition for Science and Technology Education. The lead federal agency for the program is the Department of Energy Office of Science. Other federal participants in the program include NASA, NOAA, and the U.S. Congress. In 2014-15, NSF will host ten Albert Einstein Fellows.

The Albert Einstein Fellows program is designed to provide substantial STEM work experience beyond the confines of the classroom, as well as extensive training in the fields of science, technology, and engineering, STEM education policy, and STEM program outcomes. For teachers, the program increases STEM knowledge and pedagogical skills, provides an opportunity for building leadership capabilities as STEM experts, and assists with understanding the policy process. Overall, the program brings STEM educator expertise to inform and improve communication with policymakers. The program also encourages broader diversity in STEM by recruiting in demographic sectors (race, ethnicity, location, etc.) that are historically underrepresented.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship program is designed to provide outstanding K-12 Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) teachers the opportunity to contribute their insight, expertise, and practical skills as classroom teachers to the program development efforts funded throughout NSF.  In 2014-15, nineteen Albert Einstein Fellows (AEFs) were placed in a Federal agency including the Department of Energy (DOE), the National Science Foundation (NSF), the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). Host Congressional offices included the offices of Senator Bill Nelson (D-FL), Senator Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY) and Congressman Mike Honda (D-CA). Nine of the participants were placed at NSF. 

As Albert Einstein Fellows, these master educators spend eleven months immersed in the culture of NSF. They engaged with program mangers, policy makers, and their counterparts at other federal agencies and with policy advocates in the larger STEM community throughout their appointment. 

The Fellowship affords participants time and resources to focus on their subject area interests for professional development. The experience as an Albert Einstein Fellow at NSF helps increase their understanding, cooperation, and communication on STEM education issues at a national level. The fellowship enables teachers to share ideas and research from their Fellowship experience with their school and home state throughout the fellowship year. The increased communications between local, state and national STEM policy makers will lead to more efficient policy and program development across administrative boundaries and presumably a greater shared commitment to STEM education.
